description: 1530s, from Latin accommodātus, perfect passive participle of accommodō; ad + commodō (“make fit, help”); com- + modus (“measure, proportion”) (English mode).

adjectives.description: accommodate (comparative more accommodate, superlative most accommodate)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Suitable; fit; adapted; as, means accommodate to end.

verbs.description: accommodate (third-person singular simple present accommodates, present participle accommodating, simple past and past participle accommodated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, often reflexive) To render fit, suitable, or correspondent; to adapt.
examples: Synonyms: adapt, conform, adjust, arrange, suit

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to come to agreement; to bring about harmony; to reconcile.

examples: to accommodate an old friend for a week

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide with something desired, needed, or convenient.
examples: to accommodate a friend with a loan

entries.meaning: (transitive) To do a favor or service for; to oblige.
(transitive) To show the correspondence of; to apply or make suit by analogy; to adapt or fit, as teachings to accidental circumstances, statements to facts, etc.
(transitive) To give consideration to; to allow for.
(transitive) To contain comfortably; to have space for.
examples: This venue accommodates three hundred people.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, rare) To adapt oneself; to be conformable or adapted; become adjusted.
(intransitive, of an eye) To change focal length in order to focus at a different distance.
